title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
text:
Wykonano po 5 pomiar√≥w ≈õrednic drobnego elementu produkowanego na 5 r√≥≈ºnych maszynach przy zastosowaniu dwu r√≥≈ºnych ch≈Çodziw A i B. Nale≈ºy sprawdziƒá, czy rodzaj ch≈Çodziwa ma jakikolwiek wp≈Çyw na ≈õrednicƒô wytwarzanych element√≥w.
Czynnikami wyr√≥≈ºniajƒÖcymi sƒÖ numer maszyny i rodzaj ch≈Çodziwa. Do analizy problemu wykorzystano dwuczynnikowƒÖ analizƒô wariancji, kt√≥ra bada wp≈Çyw dw√≥ch r√≥≈ºnych jako≈õciowych zmiennych niezale≈ºnych (jeden - maszyna, drugi - ch≈Çodziwo) na jednƒÖ ciƒÖg≈ÇƒÖ zmiennƒÖ zale≈ºnƒÖ (≈õrednica elementu). Przyk≈Çad i dane liczbowe zosta≈Çy wziƒôte z poradnika: https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/ppc/section2/ppc232.htm.
Dane liczbowe zosta≈Çy przedstawione w tabeli na rysunku poni≈ºej.



Pomiary ≈õrednicy \(d\) elementu w zale≈ºno≈õci od maszyny i ch≈Çodziwa.


Uk≈Çad zerowych hipotez, kt√≥re bƒôdƒÖ testowane metodƒÖ Anova:

\(H0_1\): Czynnik 1 nie wp≈Çywa na zmiennƒÖ zale≈ºnƒÖ.
\(ùêª0_2\): Czynnik 2 nie wp≈Çywa na zmiennƒÖ zale≈ºnƒÖ.
\(ùêª0_{1-2}\): Wzajemna interakcja czynnik√≥w 1 i 2 nie wp≈Çywa na zmiennƒÖ zale≈ºnƒÖ.

Analizƒô Anova i czynno≈õci przygotowawcze wykonano w R (RStudio). Analizƒô post-hoc por√≥wnania parami - w Pythonie.

title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
text:
Przygotowanie danych do analizy wariancji
Zapis danych w postaci ‚Äòdata frame‚Äô, kt√≥rej pierwszƒÖ kolumnƒÖ sƒÖ ≈õrednice, a wyr√≥≈ºnik maszyny to druga kolumna, trzecia kolumna to rodzaj ch≈Çodziwa.

n <- dim(daneA)[1]       # liczba pomiar√≥w, tzw 'powt√≥rze≈Ñ' 
m <- dim(daneA)[2]       # liczba maszyn (kolumn )
k <- 2                   # liczba poziom√≥w czynnika 1 (rodzaju ch≈Çodziwa)

nag <- colnames(daneA)   # nag≈Ç√≥wki kolumn
srednice <- data.frame(data = NA, nrow = 2*n*m,ncol =3)  # deklaracja 
for(j in seq(1,m,1)){
    for (i in seq(1,n,1)){
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,1] <- daneA[i,j]
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,2] <- nag[j]
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,3] <- "A"
    }
}

for(j in seq(1,m,1)){
    for (i in seq(1,n,1)){
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,1] <- daneB[i,j]
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,2] <- nag[j]
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,3] <- "B"
    }
}

# zamiana typu kolumn
srednice[,2] <- as.factor(srednice[,2])
srednice[,3] <- as.factor(srednice[,3])

# wprowadzenie nazw kolumn
colnames(srednice)= c("d","Maszyna", "Ch≈Çodziwo")
head(srednice)

      d  Maszyna Ch≈Çodziwo
1 0.125 Maszyna1         A
2 0.127 Maszyna1         A
3 0.125 Maszyna1         A
4 0.126 Maszyna1         A
5 0.128 Maszyna1         A
6 0.118 Maszyna2         A

title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
text:
Wykres pude≈Çkowy

require(ggplot2)
ggplot(srednice, aes(x = Maszyna, y = d,  fill = Ch≈Çodziwo) ) +
geom_boxplot()







Rysunek¬†1: Wykres pude≈Çkowy zale≈ºno≈õci \(d\) od numeru maszyny i ch≈Çodziwa

title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
text:
Wynik analizy
Anova wykaza≈Ça, ≈ºe czynnikiem wp≈ÇywajƒÖcym na wynik (≈õrednicƒô \(d\)) w spos√≥b istotny statystycznie jest Maszyna. Wynika to z warto≈õci prawdopodobie≈Ñstwa p < 0.05 tylko dla czynnika Maszyna. Rodzaj ch≈Çodziwa nie ma wp≈Çywu (p >0.05), jak r√≥wnie≈º interakcje.
Oznacza to, ≈ºe przynajmniej jedna z maszyn produkuje elementy r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô od innych w spos√≥b istotny statystycznie. W celu sprawdzenia, kt√≥re maszyny produkujƒÖ elementy r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô istotnie od innych, nale≈ºy wykonaƒá analizƒô por√≥wnania parami metodƒÖ Tukeya HSD. Analiza zosta≈Ça przeprowadzona z wykorzystaniem Pythona.

title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
section: Maszyny r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô w spos√≥b statystycznie istotny
text:
Maszyny r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô w spos√≥b statystycznie istotny

require(reticulate)                             # hub do Pythona

# liczba mo≈ºliwych kombinacji 2 r√≥≈ºnych liczb spo≈õr√≥d 5
n <- factorial(5)/factorial(2)/factorial(3)     # factorial() - silnia
kombi <- kombinacja(srednice$Maszyna)           # mo≈ºliwe kombinacje maszyn

# wyszukiwanie wynik√≥w por√≥wnania parami z prawdopodobie≈Ñstwem p < 0.05
wynik <- data.frame(NA) 
pom <- rep(0,n)
p <- rep(0,n)
j <- 0
for (i in 1:n){    
  if ( py$tuk1$pvalues[i] < 0.05 ) {    # odwo≈Çanie z poziomu R do obiektu Pythona
       j <- j+1
       pom[j] <- i
       p[j] <- py$tuk1$pvalues[i]     
  }
}

# zapis wynik√≥w wyszukiwania
for (i in 1:j){
  wynik[i,1] <- kombi[pom[i],1] 
  wynik[i,2] <- p[i] 
  wynik[i,3] <- "istotna"
}

colnames(wynik) <- c("Por√≥wnanie parami", "p", "r√≥≈ºnica")





Tabela¬†3: Maszyny r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô w spos√≥b istotny statystycznie

p

title: Dwuczynnikowa Anova - przyk≈Çad
section: Maszyny nie r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô w spos√≥b statystycznie istotny
text:
Maszyny nie r√≥≈ºniƒÖce siƒô w spos√≥b statystycznie istotny

# wyszukiwanie wynik√≥w por√≥wnania parami z prawdopodobie≈Ñstwem p > 0.05
wynik <- data.frame(NA) 
pom <- rep(0,n)
p <- rep(0,n)
j <- 0
for (i in 1:n){    
  if ( py$tuk1$pvalues[i] > 0.05 ) {    # odwo≈Çanie z poziomu R do obiektu Pythona
       j <- j+1
       pom[j] <- i
       p[j] <- py$tuk1$pvalues[i]     
  }
}

# zapis wynik√≥w wyszukiwania
for (i in 1:j){
  wynik[i,1] <- kombi[pom[i],1] 
  wynik[i,2] <- p[i] 
  wynik[i,3] <- "nieistotna"
}

colnames(wynik) <- c("Por√≥wnanie parami", "p", "r√≥≈ºnica")

title: Info
text: Jest to raport Quarto w postaci dokumentu HTML na temat zastosowania analizy wariancji w analizie danych.

title: About
text: This is a Quarto report in HTML format on the use of variance analysis in data analysis.

title: Two-way Anova - an example
text:
5 measurements have been made of the diameter of a small element produced on 5 different machines using two different coolants A and B were made. It should be checked whether the type of coolant has any effect on the diameter of the elements produced.
The distinguishing factors are the machine number and the type of coolant. The problem was analyzed using a two-way analysis of variance, which examines the effect of two different qualitative independent variables (one - machine, the other - coolant) on a continuous dependent variable (the diameter of the element). The example and the numerical data have been taken from the guide: https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/ppc/section2/ppc232.htm.
The numerical data are presented in the table in the figure below.



Measurements of the diameter \(d\) of the part as a function of the machine and the coolant.


The null hypotheses to be tested using the Anova method:

$H0_1$: Factor 1 (coolant) has no effect on the dependent variable.
$ùêª0_2$: Factor 2 (Machine) has no effect on the dependent variable.
$ùêª0_{1-2}$: The interaction of factors 1 and 2 has no effect on the dependent variable.

Anova analysis and preparatory steps were performed in R (RStudio). Post-hoc analysis of pairwise comparisons was performed in Python.

title: Two-way Anova - an example
text:
Data preparation for variance analysis
The data is recorded in the form of a ‚Äòdata frame‚Äô where the first column is the diameter, the second column is the machine factor and the third column is the coolant type.

n <- dim(daneA)[1]       # number of measurements
m <- dim(daneA)[2]       # number of machines
k <- 2                   # number of levels of factor 1 (coolant)

nag <- colnames(daneA)   
srednice <- data.frame(data = NA, nrow = 2*n*m,ncol =3)   
for(j in seq(1,m,1)){
    for (i in seq(1,n,1)){
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,1] <- daneA[i,j]
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,2] <- nag[j]
      srednice[i+(j-1)*n,3] <- "A"
    }
}

for(j in seq(1,m,1)){
    for (i in seq(1,n,1)){
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,1] <- daneB[i,j]
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,2] <- nag[j]
      srednice[n*m+i+(j-1)*n,3] <- "B"
    }
}

# columns as factors
srednice[,2] <- as.factor(srednice[,2])
srednice[,3] <- as.factor(srednice[,3])

# names of the columns
colnames(srednice)= c("d","Machine", "Coolant")
head(srednice)

      d  Machine Coolant
1 0.125 Machine1       A
2 0.127 Machine1       A
3 0.125 Machine1       A
4 0.126 Machine1       A
5 0.128 Machine1       A
6 0.118 Machine2       A

title: Two-way Anova - an example
text:
Box plot

require(ggplot2)
ggplot(srednice, aes(x = Machine, y = d,  fill = Coolant) ) +
geom_boxplot()







Rysunek¬†1: Box plot of \(d\) dependence on machine number and coolant

title: Two-way Anova - an example
text:
Results
Anova showed that the factor that influenced the result (diameter $d$) in a statistically significant way was the Machine. This is shown by the probability value of p < 0.05 for the Machine factor only. The type of coolant has no influence (p >0.05), as do the interactions.This means that at least one of the machines produces parts that differ from the others in a statistically significant way.
To see which machines produce parts that are significantly different from the others, a pairwise comparison analysis should be performed using the Tukey HSD method. The analysis was performed using Python.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import statsmodels
from scipy.stats import f_oneway
from statsmodels.stats.multicomp import pairwise_tukeyhsd

# Investigating the impact of the Machine factor
# r.srednice - a Python-level reference to an R object
tuk1 = pairwise_tukeyhsd(endog=r.srednice['d'],
                          groups=r.srednice['Machine'],
                          alpha=0.05)
print(tuk1)

  Multiple Comparison of Means - Tukey HSD, FWER=0.05   
========================================================
 group1   group2  meandiff p-adj   lower   upper  reject
--------------------------------------------------------
Machine1 Machine2  -0.0057 0.0005 -0.0093 -0.0021   True
Machine1 Machine3  -0.0024 0.3398  -0.006  0.0012  False
Machine1 Machine4   0.0005 0.9948 -0.0031  0.0041  False
Machine1 Machine5  -0.0047 0.0052 -0.0083 -0.0011   True
Machine2 Machine3   0.0033 0.0889 -0.0003  0.0069  False
Machine2 Machine4   0.0062 0.0001  0.0026  0.0098   True
Machine2 Machine5    0.001 0.9335 -0.0026  0.0046  False
Machine3 Machine4   0.0029  0.171 -0.0007  0.0065  False
Machine3 Machine5  -0.0023 0.3824 -0.0059  0.0013  False
Machine4 Machine5  -0.0052 0.0016 -0.0088 -0.0016   True
--------------------------------------------------------

# Investigating the impact of the Coolant factor
tuk2 = pairwise_tukeyhsd(endog=r.srednice['d'],
                          groups=r.srednice['Coolant'],
                          alpha=0.05)
print(tuk2)

Multiple Comparison of Means - Tukey HSD, FWER=0.05
==================================================
group1 group2 meandiff p-adj  lower  upper  reject
--------------------------------------------------
     A      B  -0.0006 0.597 -0.0027 0.0016  False
--------------------------------------------------

title: Two-way Anova - an example
section: Machines that differ in a statistically significant way
text:
Machines that differ in a statistically significant way

require(reticulate)                             # hub to Python

# number of possible combinations of 2 different numbers out of 5
n <- factorial(5)/factorial(2)/factorial(3)     
kombi <- kombinacja(srednice$Machine)           # possible combinations of Machines

# Search for results of pairwise comparisons with a probability of p < 0.05
wynik <- data.frame(NA) 
pom <- rep(0,n)
p <- rep(0,n)
j <- 0
for (i in 1:n){    
  if ( py$tuk1$pvalues[i] < 0.05 ) {    # R-level reference to a Python object
       j <- j+1
       pom[j] <- i
       p[j] <- py$tuk1$pvalues[i]     
  }
}

# search results
for (i in 1:j){
  wynik[i,1] <- kombi[pom[i],1] 
  wynik[i,2] <- p[i] 
  wynik[i,3] <- "significant"  
}

colnames(wynik) <- c("pairwise comparisons", "p", "difference")





Tabela¬†3: Machines that differ in a statistically significant way

p
difference

0.0004717

0.0051667
significant


Machine2-Machine4
0.0001330
significant


Machine4-Machine5

title: Two-way Anova - an example
text:
Machines not statistically significantly different

# Search for results of pairwise comparisons with a probability of p > 0.05
wynik <- data.frame(NA) 
pom <- rep(0,n)
p <- rep(0,n)
j <- 0
for (i in 1:n){    
  if ( py$tuk1$pvalues[i] > 0.05 ) {    # R-level reference to a Python object
       j <- j+1
       pom[j] <- i
       p[j] <- py$tuk1$pvalues[i]     
  }
}

# search results
for (i in 1:j){
  wynik[i,1] <- kombi[pom[i],1] 
  wynik[i,2] <- p[i] 
  wynik[i,3] <- "not significant" 
}

colnames(wynik) <- c("pairwise comparisons", "p", "difference")
